div.p:
My own darling Mother I had finished
my abendbrot and was feeling dispirited to
do anything in particular except look at
the sunset when your dear letter ar-
rives. After reading which, I have a
special wish for Norite Vzon at once! I
will send on your note to Frau.
He. Herzogenberg, Elisabeth von
He , who is far away in Bohemia, will
be so glad I have it. She was always
saying, especially while cooking somet-
hing for me, ' What a face it would be if
your mother were to walk in suddenly,'
except that I fear I should not be
” here in her place then！“which she
certainly would not have been. I now
go over to Frau Doctor generally about
to munch and eat ya Mittag,
and here (she says) ein satz I generally better
food there than here, which is true
— but that here is quite good enough,
and I have a good appetite). I mean
stay there all afternoon until about 6 or 7, quite alone ） in her boudoir
or on the verandah, or else without
Frau Doctor, for I am not yet allowed
to see people. For, as the Doctor says,
if one receives one or two, one must receive all, and one can't say Done. „
May come in - you don't excite me at all.
I said to another, 'You mayn't come in
You do excite me „ therefore, on must
say no at all—except on or two choice
spirits who are smuggled in for 1/2 an
hour with the greatest secrecy, and
upon whom absolute silence is
imposed! For instance, my dear Dr.Röntgen
who with his sister came and bid me
goodbye - as he is off (all the time I
am away, luckily), and a niece of
the Emperor, whose children he is
to give music lessons. He's a vio-
lin virtuoso, also composes, and
since I have been ill, has com-
posed 3 lovely little pieces dedi-
cated to me and suited, as he rather
wickedly says — to my technik!!/i.s.
not difficult. He is writing Thema
out for me - also, Frau Herzogenberg 's piano setting of the new
Brahms Symphony - but I haven’t
got them yet, and I can't let you, Mo-
ther darling, know how impatient I am
to be off, and that very impatience hin-
ders my departure - as it increases
the heart action! My pulse is
all day over 100 and not always steady—So, as you may imagine,
I have to take care. People are
so kind to me - were the Leipzig
sweet old ladies who have been
kind to me and asked me to their
houses (to whom next year I must
ruthlessly forsake). They climb up
my 2 pianos of stairs, inquire,
and leave roses, ice, biscuits, and
notes—My room is overflowing with
flowers, and the two sweetest
of the bourgeois sweets here,
Limburgers and Danzich who
have already ein Wort retired to their
several seats a few miles
out of Leipzig — send me ser-
vants with flowers and notes of in-
quiry. Isn't it touching of them!
And the melancholy thing is that I shan't be able to go and thank
them, as I have to save myself
for the journey and take things very
easily. I take about 1/4 of an hour
to get up the stairs, and I arrive more
dead than alive at the top…..
Quite like Dr.V.He ? But,
unlike her — and quite good on
level ground! Oh, Mother, I
hope the rules may be a little
relaxed! But the worst of it is
I have promised my dear foreman Doctor,
on my word of honor, signed a
paper to that effect, which I must
show you when I get home. And unless
he absolves me, I fear I can't. But
we will see, and I will hope on. Other-
wise, I often suddenly burst out
into vehement howling at the
bare idea of it, as I know my years
of devotion to the Muses has not
affected my love for field sports,
to which I know I have just as
I’ll see the lawn tennis net
for Captain Smith Captain Smith 's benefit once more
before I leave home again.
You would be so amused if you saw
me cooking . Dr. Frau Herz taught
me (or rather, I taught myself
by watching her), and now very
often, if I feel disposed there to
send for cold meat, and on a little
spirit lamp apparatus that she
has lent me, I dish up all sorts of
messes - fry potatoes , and goodness
knows what else- Once or twice, I
have sent for 1/2 a pounds of beefsteak
or undercut (8½ - the ½ lb)
2） and have cooked that as a sort
of treat – being an anomaly. The
unpleasant part is preparing the
raw meat for the cooking, +
Nacy , who was also
not brought up to that sort of thing,
is much astonished are my being
able to stomach it! But
one does get over the feeling,
+ then I am in all much more
of a nationalized German now.
Nacy , who actually won't eat
sausages because quite alone the pigs weren’t
brought up in her own pigsty!
Did one ever hear of anything so
absurd in Germany! It is won-
derful how good the food tastes
when one has removed the traces
of the kitchen and deposited them
on my small box outside the door,
donned one's looking apron (a towel
tied around the waist!)
donned one's cap— and buckles to
I flatter myself I cook such a casserole
as never was - (but whether I
can cook it in any other pot but
Frau Herz 's, which I must send her
back soon, and in which I know the
Proportions of sugar, milk, and cocoa,
and a hair – remains to be proved at
Fernhurst when I first cook the
brew at breakfast at the table
in the window among the old books
and well behind the hot things!!!
To joys - thought I don't know how
to wait till the time comes! Could
n’t you get the School piano, mother
darling, for me to practice on?
I think the ein Wort diningroom

than in the green room, where
poor Papa will have a fine time
of it between two fires above and below!!
I am in terror about the Convention.
The doctor laughed at my idea
of pottering about in the town and said I
shouldn't think of it. And I
hardly like to trust the matter to
anyone else. That for Nina and
Violet, I have (at least the
big one between them both).
